He travels from America, where he lives, joins up with a translator, the translator's grandfather who is also their driver, and the translator's grandfather's dog.All he has to go on is an old photograph of his grandfather and the young woman who helped him leave for America. Will he find the village where his grandfather came from? Why is the grandfather acting so mysterious? And who is the mysterious Augustine?I'm not even sure of the answer to these questions, even though I've seen it. I didn't really understand what they were looking for, or why it was so hard to find. And I didn't understand the ending either. I think I was just missing something.  To be honest, I wasn't sure if this was supposed to be a comedy, a drama, or something else. It didn't really have enough suspense to make it work as a mystery, and it wasn't really funny enough to be a comedy I thought. Perhaps a few more twists in the plot would have helped, or more jokes. I also found the soundtrack off-putting and annoying at times.On the other hand, my girlfriend liked it a lot. Apparently it's based on a book, though she said the film only covers half of the book, which she says is much better because you get a better idea of the history of the place he's looking for. She told me to read the book first before I jumped to conclusions, so I suppose I'll have to have a go at it and see if it all makes sense then.In short, I'd say if you've read the book, this might be a good film, but if you haven't, as I haven't, you might find it confusing.

reviewText: Man, what a surprise this movie was. Everything Is Illuminated was rented for me one Thursday night, and I must say I was disappointed at the prospect of watching it. It looked basically average based on the DVD back cover, and I figured it wasn't really worth my time to watch. WOW, WAS I WRONG. What a pleasant surprise this movie turned out to be. While I'm sure the book gets far more in-depth with the concepts of the story, the film stands by itself as a work of art, and delivers a multi-layered story that is both funny and powerful. Great stuff.Elijah Woood's performance is fine, but the film really belongs to Eugene Hutz. What a tour-de-force from this basically unknown actor! In addition, the grandfather role is performed deftly by Boris Lefkin, thus rounding out a top-notch group of actors. First-time director Liev Schreiber proves he will be a force to reckon with, as his pacing and direction sparkle.While I don't want to give away the story, as I believe not knowing too much about this film adds immeasurably to its enjoyment, it is a pretty basic "getting in touch with your past" story, with numerous original and excellent touches added. All in all, this movie was a VERY pleasant surprise for me. If you are looking for an EXCELLENT movie that is somewhat 'off the beaten path', do yourself a favor and check out Everything Is Illuminated. RECOMMENDED!!

reviewText: Can a movie find hope in the ashes of the Holocaust?  Miraculously, this one does, and with a lot less schmaltz than you might imagine possible.  How does it do this?  By giving us characters so vivid and memorable that their very presence suggests the indomitable spirit of life.  By making us laugh, cry, and  stare in wonder at sights and sounds which have the ring of truth, even if the film itself is wrought out of the colors of magical hyper-realism.A great deal of credit of course accrues to the novel.  But Liev Schreiber proves here that he understands how film can cut straight to the funny bone-- and to the heart.  And he seems to have an almost unerring sense of when to do what.A dazzling, moving, stirring debut film.  The only rub is this: when it was released by Warner Independent, nobody saw it.  Something is clearly wrong with a) how films are being distributed in America b) the American public, or (and most likely) c) both.
summary: a tragi-comic jewel of a roadtrip movie

reviewText: Though `Everything Is Illuminated' stars Elijah Wood as Jonathan Safran Foer, his role is not as impressive as you might think. He is more like a window through which we see a long history of some people he is going to meet, and those people should be called the real protagonists of the story.A young Jewish American man Jonathan (Wood) travels to Ukraine to find out the truths behind his grandfather's escape from the Nazi holocaust. He hires two local Ukrainians Alex (musician-turned-actor Eugene Hutz, who is very good) and Alex's grandfather (Boris Leskin) and dog called Sammy Davis Jr. Jr. (yes, double Jrs). The first part of the film follows their long journey by an old Trabant car, and often very funny with the quirky (and amusing) dialogues between Alex as translator and slightly nerdy Jonathan.First-time director Liev Schreiber, it seems, always insists on giving some quirky touch to the film's beautifully shot scenes and it works to some extent when the film changes its tone in the second part where the truths about Jonathan's grandfather are revealed. Look how he managed to show an old lady's house surrounded by sunflowers and you will realize Liev Schreiber gets the story's fable-like quality right.But two things I didn't like about the film and one of them is the jumbled and confusing flashbacks that play a significant role in the history of these people. The story about their past is too short and looks emotionally detached. Quirky humor certainly helps make the film less sentimental in the modern part of the story, but to present the past the film needs another kind of narrative skills to draw us into its world.The other complaint is that something is missing which might have been lost during the translating process from the book to the screen. You will notice many quirky traits in characters such as Jonathan's habit of collecting family artifacts, Alex's grandfather's denial of his seeing things, etc. What do they mean? You will think, and even reflect after watching the film, but they look almost pointless compared with the brief but touching moments involving the character played by Laryssa Lauret, who recounts her story with pain and grief. I know some films need to be interpreted by us (or I must read the book in the first place), but at the same time films can be confident with the director's own interpretation or vision as to the book's contents. I frankly didn't know how I should watch this film. Comedy? Drama? Road Movie? Or Everything?Perhaps I didn't find the film as impressive as other reviewers because, for all its strangely funny and engaging moments, what happens (and happened) is absolutely different. The film has many wonderful moments, but to me it lacks director's perspective or a context that connects them throughout.
summary: Funny and Touching, Still Something Is Missing

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***'Everything is Illuminated" is a story based on a novel by Jonathan Safran Foer who made a trip to Ukraine in 1999 to research his family history. His experiences form the basis for the novel and the subsequent screenplay, mainly penned by the film's director, well-known actor, Liev Schreiber. In the novel, Jonathan is a writer but Schreiber turns him into a very quirky caricature who is obsessed with collecting things related to his family (the 'heirlooms'--and I'm being very generous in using that word to describe what Jonathan collects--are basically anything that this oddball deems interesting). He places everything he collects in plastic baggies and then pins them on his wall at home (by the way, we never find out what this guy does for a living or if he has any friends).The inciting incident involves Jonathan's grandmother (who while on her deathbed) gives her grandson a picture of his grandfather standing next to a mysterious woman named Augustine. The picture is dated 1940 and was taken in an unknown town in Ukraine. It seems that Jonathan's grandfather managed to escape to the United States right before the Holocaust with the hope that he might be able to arrange for his pregnant first wife (the woman in the picture, Augustine) to soon follow him. Schreiber tells us that Jonathan's grandfather left a week before Augustine is murdered by the Nazis. It would seem extremely unlikely that he would have a) left his wife and/or b) successfully made it to the United States given that the vast majority of Jews had no means of leaving Ukraine and escaping the Nazis, especially with one week before the invasion and subsequent occupation.The break into the second act of the story occurs when Jonathan arrives in Ukraine and meets Alex, his genial tour guide whose command of the English language serves as the butt of many jokes throughout the film. Schrieber informs us that the grandfather, who acts as the driver, began the business back in the 50s, taking rich Jews around so that they can research their family history. Unfortunately, Schreiber gets his facts wrong since such tours would never have been permitted back then since Ukraine was a satellite of the Soviet Union (nor did Jews make pilgrimages to Ukraine to research their family history at that point in time) Much of the film's humor falls flat, especially in regards to Alex's linguistic gaffes. "The seeing eye bitch" (which refers to the 'demented' family dog) is one line which seems to be repeated too many times. Other malapropisms include Alex's reference to his brother as "miniature' instead of "younger" and the 'rigid search' for Jonathan's roots in place of 'comprehensive'. Instead of 'sleep', Alex manages to substitute the more difficult 'repose', which may be the screenwriter's way of suggesting that the character is trying to sound smarter than he is.Certainly the Ukrainians don't come off very well in this film. Schreiber (or perhaps Foer also--I haven't read the book) harp on the Ukrainians' shock at the fact that Jonathan is a vegetarian--they simply can't imagine anyone not eating meat. More damaging is Schreiber's observation that the Ukrainian family (represented by Alex and his father and grandfather) are inherently violent. Alex's father is seen slugging him at the beginning of the film--and later the grandfather attacks Alex after Alex attacks the family dog. The attempt here is to view Jonathan's hosts as affectionate--but more often than not, they come off as surly and unsympathetic.After all the failed attempts at comedy, the last quarter of the film changes gears and we're asked to take the goofy Jonathan and Alex much more seriously. They discover Augustine's elderly sister, Lista, living off the beaten track in a house hidden by a grove of perfectly kept sunflowers (while the impractical Lista has never been in a car in her entire life, one wonders how she keeps her sunflowers so perfectly arranged). It's Lista who reveals that Augustine was married to Jonathan's grandfather and was murdered by the Nazis along with her father, who refused to spit on the Torah as ordered by his executioners. One wonders how Lista herself escaped as she is clearly Jewish (she too is a 'collector' like Jonathan, saving the buried artifacts of the once thriving Jewish community she used to be part of).Lista ends up having a 'private' conversation with Alex's grandfather which triggers his repressed memories: it turns out the grandfather actually was Jewish himself and was left for dead after facing a Nazi firing squad. In the book, the grandfather is a non-Jew who must save his own family by turning in Jews; Schreiber creates a more unlikely portrait of the grandfather, a guilt-ridden Jew, who ends up committing suicide. I just couldn't buy how this irascible older codger would suddenly feel pangs of guilt (after such a long period of time) and do himself in.Finally I'm told that the memorial for the Jews that Jonathan, Alex and his grandfather discover in the empty field is not something that is likely to be found in Western Ukraine. As one Ukrainian Jewish poster has pointed out, there are more monuments to the murderers to be found there than monuments to victims of the Holocaust.While it's certainly admirable that Schreiber has done a service in once again reminding film-goers of the horrors of the Holocaust, implausibly turning Alex and his family into observant Jews after a lifetime of regarding Jewish people with suspicion, seems to be a pointless exercise in wish fulfillment. One is further disappointed with Schreiber's portrait of his detached protagonist--the quirky Jonathan--who never is believable as a real person and has no real moments of growth. In the end, the 'culture clash' between Ukrainian/Russian and Western sensibilities is decidedly weighted against the Ukrainians and the Holocaust is 'illuminated' through the unlikely suicide of one of its victims.
summary: Conflicting tales of light weight culture clash and Holocaust Survivor guilt fail to mesh

reviewText: Elijah Woods is engaging as the serious young Jewish American who embarks on a self-styled quest for the site of the Ukrainian Shtetl of his late grandfather--a village that had been annihilated by the Nazis.  An old photograph shows the young American to be a dead ringer for his grandfather--a fact that others are compelled to notice.  Aiding him in his quest is a young man from Odessa and his own grandfather, as well as their dog.  With the young local (with his own idiosyncratic version of English) as his translator, the American and his crew make their way to the sought after site, where they meet a wonderfully-kind and spiritual old woman who has established her own personal archive of the lives of the Holocaust victims.  The woman recognizes the American as the descendent of the boy she once knew, triggering a rush of touching memories.  For some these memories prove deeply troubling--for others deeply illuminating.I have read that the language spoken by the young local and his grandfather (and perhaps other characters) is the form of Russian spoken in Odessa rather than Ukrainian.  From my three semesters of college Russian long ago, I could (when aid by the subtitles) easily understand much of the simple and straightforward Russian dialogue.  I have always considered Russian the most beautiful of all the languages to which I have been exposed, and greatly enjoyed listening to its fluidly palatalized words once again.  Russians songs make up much of the soundtrack, another compelling aspect of this movie.
summary: A combination of mystical journey and Holocaust remembrance

reviewText: I've been a fan of Elijah Wood since he was a little kid, but he isn't the reason to see this film. His performance is understated to a fault. Other flaws include a score featuring Ukrainian folk/pop which gets annoying, and a very slow start, and an ending that makes the audience sad. However, the virtues greatly outweigh the misfortunes. This tale of an American Jewish accountant who hires a cut-rate tour guide in the Ukraine to search for his grandfather's World War II village and the woman who helped him escape the Nazis turns out to be close to wonderful. The Ukrainian guide and his own grandfather and their dog are hilarious companions, and that's the best part of the film. It achieves a rare feat...many laugh-out-loud moments in what is essentially an uncovering of a tragic historical event. Eugene and Boris, as the traveling companions, steal the movie from Elijah, and their dog almost steals it from them. Rent this, have patience with it, pay close attention to it, and you will have treated yourself to nearly two hours of thoughtful story-telling. Thanks, Jim Clark, for recommending it.
summary: Not quite perfect, but quite worthwhile...

reviewText: Everyting is Illuminated is a beautiful black comedy. It's a very interesting unconventional film with jokes about cultural clashes and the serves some shocking and haunting moments of unforgotten memories. The lead characters include "Jonfan", Alex, Alex' grandfather, and "Jonfan's long estranged grandmother are brilliantly writen and portrayed by performances that was funny and touching. The various kinds of jokes between "Jonfan" and Alex were very funny at times. Even being a vegetarian is something of unconceivable in Alex's world. "Jonfan" relentlessly search for things to remind him of important events is the main plot, and it's the journey in foreign land that opens him up to the strange and haunting long lost memories of the people he encounters. He subjects himself to another cultural and the object-collecting hobby becomes less important than learning about the lives of the characters through those situations. The film is strange looking based on the style of camera work and flashbacks. The music score is very appropiate for a story like this. There are some beautiful exterior scenes. Considered that I have never seen the supporting actors in this film, I was quite taken by their performances. As for Elijah Wood, it seemed as though this potential star-showcase role had neglected to allow him to show enough range. It's interesting to see him the way he's dressed, makeup, hair, and expressions in this film. Suddenly, I am reminded of similarity between his role and Thora Birch in Ghost World.
summary: Funny, Fascinating, Haunting, and I am not using the "N" word.

reviewText: I've yet to read the book (of the same title) by Jonathan Safran Foer, but I found this movie adaptation directed by Liev Schreiber (who has been in several Holocaust-themed dramas, such as "Jakob the Liar" and most recently "Defiance") to be engrossing and entertaining with a blend of both the comic and tragic. This is quite impressive considering the movie marks Schreiber's directorial debut.The story centers around a young Jewish man, Jonathan Safran Foer (played by Elijah Wood) who has a penchant for collecting things in little ziploc bags, ranging from the ordinary to the truly bizarre(his grandmother's dentures). This obsessive collecting is due to his fear of forgetting the past, and when his dying grandmother passes him two keepsakes that belonged to his deceased grandfather, Jonathan decides to travel to Odessa, Ukraine in an attempt to discover his grandfather's past. One of these keepsakes is a picture with his grandfather Safran and a young woman who apparently saved Safran from the Nazis during WW II. To aid him on his quest, Jonathan hires two guides, Alexander Perchov (Eugene Hutz in a brilliant performance) who is obsessed with Michael Jackson, and his grouchy and anti-Semitic grandfather (Boris Laskin who also delivers a powerful performance). Grandpa has a psychotic dog named Sammy Davis Jr. Jr. (go figure) and the trio proceed on their journey - destination is Trachimbrod, which used to be a Jewish shtetl.Most of the movie focuses on the road trip and is quite hilarious, especially in watching the dynamics of three very different people travelling together. Grandpa's virulent anti-Semitism is softened by Alex's creative translation efforts (since Grandpa only speaks Ukrainian, Jonathan relies on Alex to translate for him). I could not help but laugh out loud at Alex's overzealous attempts at speaking English - "Do you repose?" he asks Jonathan, eliciting a sort of "huh" response until Jonathan figures out he means "sleeping"! The last third of the movie focuses on what happens to the trip after they finally find a home in the countryside where an old woman (Laryssa Lauret) helps Jonathan find some closure. There are also some interesting twists in the story at this point, with some startling revelations.I found this a refreshing Holocaust-themed drama. The Holocaust by its very subject matter is hard to depict on screen without resorting to the usual depictions of stomach-churning brutality (as evidenced by dramas like "Schindler's List", "The Grey Zone", "War and Remembrance", and "Holocaust", amongst others). In "Everything Is Illuminated" there is a balance between the tragic and the comic, and even the flashbacks to the past involving violence is subtly done. The focal point here is not so much the horrors of the Holocaust but of people searching for closure and making peace with events of the past. The strong cast makes this an above-average film, delivering credible and compelling performances. The cinematography is gorgeous, capturing the lush beauty of the countryside. The DVD itself contains no bonus worth mentioning (just some deleted scenes and a trailer). Final verdict - compelling and engaging drama.
summary: Everything is illuminated in the light of the past
